posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.com:
>>14358774
>The Challenge, Andrew Lambert.
About the war of 1812, specifically the naval war and economic war.
>The British Way of War, Andrew Lambert. Ostensibly a biography of Sir Julian Corbett, but deals a lot with the pre-WW1 debates about national strategy in Great Britain.
>Thunder on the Danube (3 vols), John H. Gill
About the war of the war of the 5th coalition. One of the best Napoleonic campaign histories I've read.
>England in the Seven Years War: A Study in Combined Strategy (2 vols), Sir Julian S. Corbett
Title says it all, its main focus is in examining the war from a lessons learned perspective rather than a purely historical one.
>Some Principles of Maritime Strategy, Sir Julian S. Corbett
This is really a doctrinal primer from 1907, but it's very eye opening if you have any interest in historical seapower. Makes it far easier to understand the why's of many decisions at sea.
>The Roman War of Antiochus the Great, John D. Grainger
A detailed study of the conflict between Rome and the Seleucids
>Antigonus the One Eyed and the Creation of the Hellenistic State, Richard Billows
One half is a biography of Antigonus and the other half is an examination of how the Hellenistic states developed post-Alexander
>The End of the Bronze Age, Robert Drews
This is a really interesting book regarding the Bronze Age collapse, Drews argues that their was no great migration and that the sea peoples etc, were just the normal dwellers around the fringes of society who'd learnt how to destroy chariot armies and just wanted to kill, burn and maim.

Levy's "Conquistador" is has a fair amount of issues, I remember I read the first 10 pages or so and already noticed multiple major errors per page.

>when it was the tribes oppressed by the Mexica for years that took an opportunity to wreck vengeance on them.


This is a misconception.

There were no "tribes": Mesoamerican had urbanized state societies with cities and formal governments for thousands of years by this point. Basically every society the Aztec bothered to conquer or interact with were city-states, kingdoms., and empires;

Secondly, while the Mexica of Tenochtitlan were warmongering expansionists, they were hands off with the places they actually conquered, generally speaking. This is true of most large Mesoamerican empires, but the Aztec did things like installing rulers on conquered subjects etc less then other large Mesoamerican states: They basically just demanded taxes of economic goods, military service, and that roads not be blocked alongside a few other basic obligations, with subjects keeping their, laws, customs, etc. Sacrifices was something everybody did, and were mostly captured enemy soldiers from wars.

The reason Cortes got allies is that this hands off system enabled subject states to both act independently and have their own political ambitions, so you regularly had subjects seceding and launching coups opportunistically:

State X allying or pledging themselves as a subject to state Y (since subjects got left alone anyways) to take out their existing captial or political rivals, so then X could be in higher standing in Y's new kingdom, was a common method of political advancement. That's pretty much why Cortes and other conquistadors got allies, andt he Aztec empire itself was founded this way: Cortes was basically being used.

See: https://pastebin.com/VqW97h93

>>14359233
>If anybody has any good books on the History of Shintoism and Shinto pre-Meji Restoration I'm looking for recommendations
Sorry for the late response but if you're still in this thread I'd recommend Shinto: A History by Helen Hardacre and A New History of Shinto by John Breen and Mark Teeuwen for basic stuff on Shinto in premodern Japan. If you want to learn about Edo period Shinto specifically I'd also recommend Religion, Power, and the Rise of Shinto in Early Modern Japan by Stefan Kock, Remembering Paradise: Nativism and Nostalgia in Eighteenth Century Japan by Peter Nosco, From Country to Nation: Ethnographic Studies, Kokugaku, and Spirits in Nineteenth Century Japan by Gideon Fujiwara, and Proving the Way: Conflict and Practice in the History of Japanese Nativism by Mark McNally. All of those books focus on the kokugaku movement that flourished in the Tokugawa Shogunate and was heavily involved with Shinto due to its status as a native Japanese religion (they pretty much laid the groundwork for modern Shinto as it would emerge in the Meiji Era).

>>14372128
In the original-language text, the two occurrences of “God” (Greek, the·osʹ) at John 1:1 are grammatically different.

In the first occurrence, the word “God” is preceded by the Greek definite article, while the article does not appear before the second occurrence. Many scholars note that the absence of the definite article before the second the·osʹ is significant.

For example, The Translator’s New Testament says regarding this absence of the article: “In effect it gives an adjectival quality to the second use of Theos (God) so that the phrase means ‘The Word was divine.’” (The Translator’s New Testament, page 451.)

Other scholars and Bible translations point to this same distinction.

Scholar Jason David BeDuhn states that the absence of the definite article makes the two occurrences of “God” “as different as ‘a god’ is from ‘God’ in English.” He adds: “In John 1:1, the Word is not the one-and-only God, but is a god, or divine being.”—Truth in Translation: Accuracy and Bias in English Translations of the New Testament, pages 115, 122, and 123.

posts.com:
The feminist movement is over one hundred years old, and yet it's only in the past ten years that it has come under any remotely sustained criticism or pushback in the West.

Even outside the West, in places like Japan and South Korea, South and Southeast Asia, and much of Africa, feminist ideas, laws, and thinking mostly gained ground even if somewhat slowly throughout the 20th century (voting rights, education, increased rights for women in divorce, more rights for women in physical and sexual abuse cases, access to contraception and abortion, financial autonomy, etc.).

Feminism has been so stupefyingly successful that its opponents are forced to cling to tiny victories, like the Taliban returning to power in Afghanistan, the election of a president somewhat frosty towards feminism in South Korea, abortion being returned to the states by the US Supreme Court, etc.

Meanwhile, whole regions are still becoming more and more feminist all the time, more and more feminist norms in education, dating, marriage...

>>14371134
Because Kant is incredibly useful once one knows what he's actually talking about. His whole project is one of examining the "cognitive equipment", as it were, and figuring out precisely what kinds of tasks the tools in question are employed in. Mind you, it is a detailed and rigorous study meant to properly define and delimit the types of knowledge and the method employed in arriving at said knowledge, as well as the mental categories that frame our basic understanding and furnish us with the ideas that we use to explain the world of experience. The dynamic interplay of mind with experience is central to Kant's philosophy.

The only pitfall in his system which he is unable to escape from is the absence of rational justification for belief in the "noumena" or 'external reality apart from its mediation to us by perception', hence the accusations of Kant being a fountainhead of philosophical skepticism. When the individual mind becomes the starting point of all knowledge, keeping in mind that knowledge is itself a product of reflection on internal or external experience, then there is really no rational way to ascribe certainty to a mind-independent reality. After all, as Hume stated, all I really experience directly is a sequence of events presented to me via my sense organs (i.e. My eye sees a hand punch a wall, my skin feels the abrasion of the brick, and my ears hear a crunch as my knuckles shatter), that I arbitrarily assign causal significance too. I don't really know if X causes Y to happen, nor if X or Y even exist outside my perceiving them. All I know is the sequence.

The upshot of this subjectivist tendency in Kant is that what we 'feel' or experience within ourselves becomes the criteria for our most deeply held convictions and beliefs, whether about God, ethics, or society at large. Each individual becomes autonomous in his or her decision-making and truth-judging capacity, and appeals to 'natural law' no longer have the same weight as before

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You can't refute him though

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14371134
"Humanism," what you're actually describing, was invented by the Venetians/Pisans as an "antithesis" to Kabbalism -- also created by the same families. It's about them carving up and dividing the world among themselves, you're not even a forethought.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14373643
Obviously, Kant tried to remedy this paradox of a mind unable to provide a rational account for itself or the certainty of its knowledge subsisting within a world that is molded by its own mental categories by appealing to "practical reason", which, if you manage to pierce through his obfuscating terminology, simply means common sense. Nevertheless, his philosophical method yields a thoroughly self-enclosed system that provides no satisfactory answers in the final analysis. Hence why later thinkers such as Fichte, Schelling, and Hegel would dispense with the 'noumena' and 'phenomena' distinction and posit a single unified reality that manifests itself outwardly as "material substance" and inwardly as "mind" or "spirit", or in Schopenhauer's case, the noumena becomes our "will" or "drive". Obviously, German idealism owes much to Spinoza and Indian schools of philosophy in that regard, but that is another discussion altogether.

Overall, I think Kant is a fantastic thinker in terms of cultivating a deeper understanding of how the conscious and subconscious mind operates when approaching on different tasks, forming beliefs, and the methods employed throughout, but he certainly drops the ball on epistemic certainty and ethical maxims.

Whenever I have occasion to reread Kant and find him lacking in satisfactory answers, I inevitably turn to Thomas Reid and the formulations of Common Sense Realism articulated by him and those canny Scots following after him. Reid's corpus, written in the context of rebutting Hume and in the process anticipating the exact same issues later to be discussed by Kant and yet resolving them in a succinct and conclusively argued manner, is a glorious thing to behold.

As I posted in a previous thread, Reidian epistemology and a modified metaphysical Thomism is the endgame of philosophy.

Kind of, it was how stress was determined and it was distinctive between grammatical cases, e.g. in the 1st declension the ending -a is nominative/vocative but the ending -a (long) is ablative. Also you have distinctions such as anus and anus (long a) which are separate words.
>I don't know what consonants changed.
It's not much. 'c' before 'e, i, ae, oe, y' is pronounced like English 'ch'. The letter 'g' before those same letters is pronounced like the English 'j'. Intervocalic 'h' is pronounced like 'k', e.g. in nihil or mihi. The consonants 'ti' followed by a vowel and preceded by another vowel or consant (other than 's') are pronounced like 'tsi', so laetitia is pronounced 'leh-tee-tsee-ah'. Also in vowels, ae and oe are no longer diphthongs but are pronounced the same as the letter 'e'. 'y' is no longer pronounced as in Greek/French but the same as 'i'. I think that's everything.

>This is maybe important if you're writing, but if you're speaking it all gets jumbled anyways...
I actually dvocate that people do not use the classical pronunciation (for a number of reasons). I'm just talking about the facts of the differences.
>And this is what I mean by people bringing their accents.
This is actually what occurred literally. In the past, after Latin ceased to be anyone's native language, Latin was read in accordance with the sounds of one's own native language. So there was an Italian pronunciation, a German pronunciation, an English pronunciation, etc. The German is still used in some ecclesiastical and musical settings. The English is still used commonly in our language itself, e.g. our pronunciations of Julius Caesar, et cetera, Hercules, etc. The Italian was adopted broadly in IIRC the 19th century due to ultramontanist tendencies within Catholicism, and outside of Catholic countries the native pronunciation was abandoned in favor of the reconstructed classical around that same time.

>line
Easier for command & control then a skirmishing line. Maximizing the available firepower. Having enough mass to fend of a cavalry or infantry charge.
>trenches
Commonly used in sieges.
>Why not in open field battles?
Because you would get outmaneuvered. Still rudamentary earthworks were part of certain field battles such as the Bagration Flèches during the Battle of Borodino.
>cover
Was used when available - so not really in an open field. But fighting in woods, hedges and houses was common. Especially houses often formed strong points in defensive positions.
>bring cover
Like sandbags?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mass formations were good in open fields for controlled fire. Cover was useful in some situations, but it essentially meant you would not be advancing on the enemy and you'd be surrendering initiative to them, allowing them to maneuver however they wished. This was an era where cavalry was still very important, and allowing the enemy's cavalry to have the run of the battlefield by entrenching yourself could lead to getting outflanked.

Remember this is pre-modern warfare, there's no railroads or automobiles. If you're not lucky enough to be near a navigable river or the ocean, your only line of supply is horse-drawn wagons which are ponderously slow and vulnerable to raids from, say, a bunch of cavalry you did nothing to stop outflanking you. Your entrenchment is going to look very silly in a few days once you run out of food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14369363
The point of battle isn't to kill the enemy so much as to take strategic positions. If you hold all the strategic positions in an area you can force the enemy to retreat so they can find other strategic positions, and so it becomes a many month game of chasing your enemy around until they tire or run out of supplies. Battles are extraordinarily rare, and most engagements are just skirmishes where the armies are trying to reposition themselves. WW1 devolved into trench warfare because there were enough soldiers present to cover the entire battlefield so every position needed to be turned into a strategic position as opposed to two army groups chasing each other around.

>The toilets of a castle were usually built into the walls so that they projected out on corbels and any waste fell below and into the castle moat. posts.name: Anonymous

>The only respite from constant labor the slave has through the whole year, is during the Christmas holidays. Epps allowed us three—others allow four, five and six days, according to the measure of their generosity. It is the only time to which they look forward with any interest or pleasure. They are glad when night comes, not only because it brings them a few hours repose, but because it brings them one day nearer Christmas. It is hailed with equal delight by the old and the young; even Uncle Abram ceases to glorify Andrew Jackson, and Patsey forgets her many sorrows, amid the general hilarity of the holidays. It is the time of feasting, and frolicking, and fiddling—the carnival season with the children of bondage. They are the only days when they are allowed a little restricted liberty, and heartily indeed do they enjoy it.
>It is the custom for one planter to give a "Christmas supper," inviting the slaves from neighboring plantations to join his own on the occasion; for instance, one year it is given by Epps, the next by Marshall, the next by Hawkins, and so on. Usually from three to five hundred are assembled, coming together on foot, in carts, on horseback, on mules, riding double and triple, sometimes a boy and girl, at others a girl and two boys, and at others again a boy, a girl and an old woman. Uncle Abram astride a mule, with Aunt Phebe and Patsey behind him, trotting towards a Christmas supper, would be no uncommon sight on Bayou Bœuf.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14373300
>Then, too, "of all days i' the year," they array themselves in their best attire. The cotton coat has been washed clean, the stump of a tallow candle has been applied to the shoes, and if so fortunate as to possess a rimless or a crownless hat, it is placed jauntily on the head. They are welcomed with equal cordiality, however, if they come bare-headed and barefooted to the feast. As a general thing, the women wear handkerchiefs tied about their heads, but if chance has thrown in their way a fiery red ribbon, or a cast-off bonnet of their mistress' grandmother, it is sure to be worn on such occasions. Red—the deep blood red—is decidedly the favorite color among the enslaved damsels of my acquaintance. If a red ribbon does not encircle the neck, you will be certain to find all the hair of their woolly heads tied up with red strings of one sort or another.
>The table is spread in the open air, and loaded with varieties of meat and piles of vegetables. Bacon and corn meal at such times are dispensed with. Sometimes the cooking is performed in the kitchen on the plantation, at others in the shade of wide branching trees. In the latter case, a ditch is dug in the ground, and wood laid in and burned until it is filled with glowing coals, over which chickens, ducks, turkeys, pigs, and not unfrequently the entire body of a wild ox, are roasted. They are furnished also with flour, of which biscuits are made, and often with peach and other preserves, with tarts, and every manner and description of pies, except the mince, that being an article of pastry as yet unknown among them. Only the slave who has lived all the years on his scanty allowance of meal and bacon, can appreciate such suppers. White people in great numbers assemble to witness the gastronomical enjoyments.

>They seat themselves at the rustic table—the males on one side, the females on the other. The two between whom there may have been an exchange of tenderness, invariably manage to sit opposite; for the omnipresent Cupid disdains not to hurl his arrows into the simple hearts of slaves. Unalloyed and exulting happiness lights up the dark faces of them all. The ivory teeth, contrasting with their black complexions, exhibit two long, white streaks the whole extent of the table. All round the bountiful board a multitude of eyes roll in ecstacy. Giggling and laughter and the clattering of cutlery and crockery succeed. Cuffee's[Pg 216] elbow hunches his neighbor's side, impelled by an involuntary impulse of delight; Nelly shakes her finger at Sambo and laughs, she knows not why, and so the fun and merriment flows on.

>
When the viands have disappeared, and the hungry maws of the children of toil are satisfied, then, next in the order of amusement, is the Christmas dance. My business on these gala days always was to play on the violin. The African race is a music-loving one, proverbially; and many there were among my fellow-bondsmen whose organs of tune were strikingly developed, and who could thumb the banjo with dexterity; but at the expense of appearing egotistical, I must, nevertheless, declare, that I was considered the Ole Bull of Bayou Bœuf. My master often received letters, sometimes from a distance of ten miles, requesting him to send me to play at a ball or festival of the whites. He received his compensation, and usually I also returned with many picayunes jingling in my pockets—the extra contributions of those to whose delight I had administered. In this manner I became more acquainted than I otherwise would, up and down the bayou. The young men and maidens of Holmesville always knew there was to be a jollification somewhere, whenever Platt Epps was seen passing through the town with his fiddle in his hand. "Where are you going now, Platt?" and "What is coming off to-night, Platt?" would be interrogatories issuing from every door and window, and many a time when there was no special hurry, yielding to pressing importunities, Platt would draw his bow, and sitting astride his mule, perhaps, discourse musically to a crowd of delighted children, gathered around him in the street.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14373312
>Alas! had it not been for my beloved violin, I scarcely can conceive how I could have endured the long years of bondage. It introduced me to great houses—relieved me of many days' labor in the field—supplied me with conveniences for my cabin—with pipes and tobacco, and extra pairs of shoes, and oftentimes led me away from the presence of a hard master, to witness scenes of jollity and mirth. It was my companion—the friend of my bosom—triumphing loudly when I was joyful, and uttering its soft, melodious consolations when I was sad. Often, at midnight, when sleep had fled affrighted from the cabin, and my soul was disturbed and troubled with the contemplation of my fate, it would sing me a song of peace. On holy Sabbath days, when an hour or two of leisure was allowed, it would accompany me to some quiet place on the bayou bank, and, lifting up its voice, discourse kindly and pleasantly indeed. It heralded my name round the country—made me friends, who, otherwise would not have noticed me—gave me an honored seat at the yearly feasts, and secured the loudest and heartiest welcome of them all at the Christmas dance. The Christmas dance! Oh, ye pleasure-seeking sons and daughters of idleness, who move with measured step, listless and snail-like, through the slow-winding cotillon, if ye wish to look[Pg 218] upon the celerity, if not the "poetry of motion"—upon genuine happiness, rampant and unrestrained—go down to Louisiana, and see the slaves dancing in the starlight of a Christmas night.

>On that particular Christmas I have now in my mind, a description whereof will serve as a description of the day generally, Miss Lively and Mr. Sam, the first belonging to Stewart, the latter to Roberts, started the ball. It was well known that Sam cherished an ardent passion for Lively, as also did one of Marshall's and another of Carey's boys; for Lively was lively indeed, and a heart-breaking coquette withal. It was a victory for Sam Roberts, when, rising from the repast, she gave him her hand for the first "figure" in preference to either of his rivals. They were somewhat crest-fallen, and, shaking their heads angrily, rather intimated they would like to pitch into Mr. Sam and hurt him badly. But not an emotion of wrath ruffled the placid bosom of Samuel, as his legs flew like drum-sticks down the outside and up the middle, by the side of his bewitching partner. The whole company cheered them vociferously, and, excited with the applause, they continued "tearing down" after all the others had become exhausted and halted a moment to recover breath. But Sam's superhuman exertions overcame him finally, leaving Lively alone, yet whirling like a top. Thereupon one of Sam's rivals, Pete Marshall, dashed in, and, with might and main, leaped and shuffled and threw himself into every conceivable shape, as if determined to show Miss Lively and all the world that Sam Roberts was of no account.

>During the remaining holidays succeeding Christmas, they are provided with passes, and permitted to go where they please within a limited distance, or they may remain and labor on the plantation, in which case they are paid for it. It is very rarely, however, that the latter alternative is accepted. They may be seen at these times hurrying in all directions, as happy looking mortals as can be found on the face of the earth. They are different beings from what they are in the field; the temporary relaxation, the brief deliverance from fear, and from the lash, producing an entire metamorphosis in their appearance and demeanor. In visiting, riding, renewing old friendships, or, perchance, reviving some old attachment, or pursuing whatever pleasure may suggest itself, the time is occupied. Such is "southern life as it is," three days in the year, as I found it—the other three hundred and sixty-two being days of weariness, and fear, and suffering, and unremitting labor.

>Marriage is frequently contracted during the holidays, if such an institution may be said to exist among them. The only ceremony required before entering into that "holy estate," is to obtain the consent of the respective owners. It is usually encouraged by the masters of female slaves. posts.name: Anonymous

>Old Abram was a kind-hearted being—a sort of patriarch among us, fond of entertaining his younger brethren with grave and serious discourse. He was deeply versed in such philosophy as is taught in the cabin of the slave; but the great absorbing hobby of Uncle Abram was General Jackson, whom his young master in Tennessee had followed to the wars. He loved to wander back, in imagination, to the place where he was born, and to recount the scenes of his youth during those stirring times when the nation was in arms. He had been athletic, and more keen and powerful than the generality of his race, but now his eye had become dim, and his natural force abated. Very often, indeed, while discussing the best method of baking the hoe-cake, or expatiating at large upon the glory of Jackson, he would forget where he left his hat, or his hoe, or his basket; and then would the old man be laughed at, if Epps was absent, and whipped if he was present. So was he perplexed continually, and sighed to think that he was growing aged and going to decay. Philosophy and Jackson and forgetfulness had played the mischief with him, and it was evident that all of them combined were fast bringing down the gray hairs of Uncle Abram to the grave.

Also, new info from an upcoming paper.

>Eurasia has been populated by modern humans for over 45,000 years and for the vast majority of their time they relied on a foraging lifestyle. Our knowledge of the genetic relatedness and structure of European hunter-gatherers is, however, still limited, because dedicated studies are challenged by the scarce availability and poor molecular preservation of human remains from that period. Here we analyze 356 ancient hunter-gatherer genomes including new genomic data of 116 individuals from 14 countries in western and central Eurasia, dating between 35,000 and 5,000 years ago (35-5 ka). We identify a new genetic ancestry profile in individuals associated with the Upper Paleolithic Gravettian from western Europe, which is distinct from contemporaneous groups related to this archeological culture in central and southern Europe. However, it resembles that of preceding individuals associated with the Aurignacian and survives during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, ~25-19 ka) in human populations from southwestern Europe, associated with the Solutrean and later Magdalenian, which re-expanded northward and northeastward after the LGM. Conversely, we reveal a genetic turnover in southern Europe suggesting a local replacement of human groups during the LGM, alongside a north-to-south expansion of Epigravettian-associated populations. From at least 14 ka, a lineage related to this culture expands from the south across the rest of Europe largely replacing the Magdalenian-associated gene pool. After a period of limited admixture across the beginning of the Mesolithic, we find genetic interactions between western and eastern European hunter-gatherers, also characterized by marked differences in inherited phenotypic traits.

>>14370106
But that is not what Paul is saying here. For example, if a gangster named Percival Grabonski had the nickname of “Mailman Mike,” we would consider that as an exclusive single unitized title of two words. We might even say, “There is only one 'Mailman Mike'; he’s unique.” The whole thing (both words: “Mailman” and “Mike”) taken together as a multi-worded, but ‘unitized,’ whole, then, is the complete title.

However, if we knew a young man named Mike who delivered our mail every morning, we might tell someone, “This town has only one mailman, Mike.”

In this case the title is “mailman” alone, and “Mike” is an appositive or identifier added to that single title to further identify which “mailman.”

Since it is not an exact exclusive title, it could even be phrased differently: “Mike is our only mailman;” “only one letter carrier, Mike;” “only one mail deliverer, Mike;” etc. When the writer (or speaker) intends it in this ‘title with appositive’ manner, the phrase may be understood as actually saying: “only one mailman, [and that is] Mike.”

posts.name: JWanon
posts.com:
>>14370106
On the other hand, the gangster’s unitized title will not be phrased differently. He wouldn’t be called “Mailman Mike” one time and “Mike the Letter Carrier” or “Mike the Postal Person” the next time. His exclusive, distinguishing unitized title is “Mailman Mike” and that won’t change (even though he may pick up additional, different titles, e.g. “Percy the Purse-snatcher”).

In one case, then (e.g., “mailman, Mike”), we have a single-word title (e.g., “mailman”) followed by a word or words (sometimes even set off by commas in English) which identify that individual. In the other case (e.g., “Mailman Mike”) we have a full title composed of two or more words which must be taken together as a complete unit (“unitized”). Don't forget that in the original manuscripts there was no punctuation or Capitalization. These have been added by modern translators as they see fit.

Naturally during the Sabellian controversy they would have referred to other passages that deal with the Personhood and Divinity of Christ. What would be the point in referring to 1 John 5:7 in a dispute about the divinity of Christ if they were already trying to misinterpret John 10:30 against it? And furthermore if the Arians had been using copies of 1 John with the content of this verse removed, then quoting it as if it was the only source for doctrine on the Trinity would be misleading. And yet, I have four sources that do quote 1 John 5:7 anyway, so the point you've made here is actually superfluous anyway.

The only reason the narrative about this verse supposedly never being quoted appeared is because people who are biased against it were looking for narratives to use to make the verse look spurious. It's similar to how the same group of scholars, in modern times, manufactured a myth about Erasmus adding the verse, which has likewise been shown to be historically inaccurate. But since it served their goal of delegitimizing 1 John 5:7, they propagated it, just as they propagate the myth that nobody used this verse in any Trinitarian controversies.

posts.com:
By the way, source 1 for the quotation of 1 John 5:7 is the pic here. >>14371726
The second source is the picture attached here: >>14372497
These are both references to this verse by Cyprian in the 3rd century. There is another source even older than these coming from another early church writer, Tertullian. And his reference those who are familiar with the totality of the evidence have also referred to as decisive evidence in favor of inclusion for 1 John 5:7, but on inspection the reference by Tertullian in my view somewhat less clear than the other three. He references it a little less directly than Cyprian does in the above sources.

I also have here a fourth source of the quote coming from Origen, another early church writer, who quotes the ending of the verse 1 John 5:7 almost verbatim in his commentary on Psalm 123.

It's clear that someone in early Christian history removed the verse in 1 John. That much is clear. Likely this was a motivated change in order to prop up a heresy, similar to what Marcion had done at an earlier stage - which was then spread by others who favored the shortened epistle of John. The variant may also have originated as a scribe who simply missed a line, but the variant then was propagated by others (such as the Arians in the East) for similar motivations as above. Regardless of how or why, the attempt to erase all evidence of this verse, as well as several others, has failed because they simply can't eliminate all of the evidence for it. This verse in 1 John is in a similar situation as the case of the phrase, "of them that are saved," in Revelation 21:24, and the use of the phrase "book of life" (instead of "tree of life") in 22:19. There is plenty of evidence for it. But the detractors, in the zeal of their bias, have simply made a dishonest show in their books and in their talks, of acting like there isn't any evidence for these Scriptures.

>The "Feast of the Circumcision of our Lord" is a Christian celebration of the circumcision, eight days (according to the Semitic and southern European calculation of intervals of days) after his birth, the occasion on which the child was formally given his name, Jesus, a name derived from Hebrew meaning "salvation" or "saviour". > but there's a weird thing in evangelical world and reformed theology about the literal blood being the whole point of the atonement. they claim they're "washed in the blood" as the reason they can now sin and still be saved.

I can tell you that no Catholic would find that weird. The idea of being washed in the blood of the Lamb - which rests on the express teaching of scripture, Revelation 1:5, 7:14, etc - is very familiar to Catholics. Indeed, it is foundational to the understanding of the forgiveness of sins.

>>14360839
It wasn't. There was a constant string of mass murders and war crimes committed by American troops throughout the entire decade of American involvement in the war.
Every major American unit in Vietnam, down to the brigade, had "incidents" wherein Vietnamese civilians were abused, murdered, and raped. The only thing exceptional about My Lai was its scope, killing hundreds at once was a step too far that couldn't be hidden. But the brutalization and killings of civilians was routine.
Even the most cursory examination of the evidence shows this, and it isn't even hidden or disputed. The US military's own analysis showed that during Operation Speedy Express, for example, 5000-7000 of the 10000 Vietnamese killed were civilians. The most outrageous stories there coming from the helicopter and light plane crews that admitted to military investigators that they constantly just murdered anyone they saw for any reason they could think of.
The ubiquitous search and destroy missions were much more up close and personal. Many times these were just covers for the wholesale destruction of a village that happened to be close to a place where a Viet Cong ambush had taken place, or where a GI had gotten injured or killed by a trap or mine. Troops bombed the village, rolled in, burned the houses, killed the livestock, raped the women, and then killed them along with anyone else they could get their hands on. I suggest you read Jamie Henry's account of one such attack. The highlight is really something, and it was attested to by multiple witnesses to military investigators. Or you could read about Roy Bumgarner, who was known as a murderer among troops and was convicted of manslaughter after gunning down four civilians and blowing their heads up with a grenade to teach some new recruits how to conduct themselves.
I can't do the extent of the violence justice, there is too much and I get too angry. I highly advise you look into this, what happened in Vietnam was pure evil.

>The program, which lasted from 1967 to 1972, was designed to identify and destroy the Viet Cong (VC) via infiltration, torture, capture, counter-terrorism, interrogation, and assassination. The CIA described it as "a set of programs that sought to attack and destroy the political infrastructure of the Viet Cong." The Phoenix Program was premised on the idea that North Vietnamese infiltration had required local support within noncombat civilian populations, which were referred to as the "VC infrastructure" and "political branch" that had purportedly coordinated the insurgency.

>Throughout the program, Phoenix "neutralized" 81,740 people suspected of VC membership, of whom 26,369 were killed, and the rest surrendered or were captured.

>The Phoenix Program was heavily criticized on various grounds, including the number of neutral civilians killed, the nature of the program (which critics have labelled as a "civilian assassination program,"[7]) the use of torture and other coercive methods, and the program being exploited for personal politics. Nevertheless, the program was very successful at suppressing Viet Cong political and revolutionary activities.[7] Public disclosure of the program led to significant criticism, including hearings by the US Congress, and the CIA was pressured to shut it down. A similar program, Plan F-6, continued under the government of South Vietnam.

There is a common misunderstanding that there is no food in communism, but this is not accurate. In a communist society, the means of production, including farms and food production facilities, are owned and controlled by the community as a whole rather than by private individuals or corporations. The goal of communism is to provide for the basic needs of all members of society, including food, shelter, and medical care.

However, it is true that some countries that have attempted to implement communist systems have experienced difficulties in providing sufficient food for their populations. This can be due to a variety of factors, such as mismanagement, economic disruption, natural disasters, and external pressures. It is important to recognize that these difficulties are not inherent to communism as an ideology, but rather are the result of specific historical and political circumstances.
